**G.L. c. 186, \u00a714**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for actual and statutory damages.

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair the defective entry door lock, despite repeated notice, constitutes an **indirect interference** with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment and peaceful habitation, as recognized in **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s phrase that a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” of residential premises is liable, and applies it to a landlord’s failure, after repeated notice, to remedy unsanitary flooding conditions. The court holds that a landlord’s reckless omission to correct such conditions, where the natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s occupancy, constitutes an (indirect) interference with quiet enjoyment under the statute. While the facts involve flooding rather than a door lock, the legal principle of liability for indirect interference by failure to repair after notice directly supports the proposition.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “In 1973, the statute was rewritten… The requirement of intentional conduct was retained for failure to provide essential services, but deleted from the quiet enjoyment clause; landlords were now liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment of leased premises. One natural inference from this amendment is that the Legislature meant to abrogate the requirement of specific intent to disturb quiet enjoyment.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: In **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord may be liable for failing to control conditions emanating from premises under their control that disturb a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses landlord liability for conditions emanating from premises the landlord controls that interfere with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. The court holds that because the landlords created the situation by leasing space for a lounge and retained the right and ability to control the objectionable noise, they breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and could not collect rent. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord may be liable for failing to control such disturbing conditions.
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge and that the judge was warranted in finding as a fact that the landlords could control the objectionable conditions…. Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

**Dorgan v. Loukas**, 19 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly found liability for failure to act upon notice of unsafe or intrusive conditions in common areas, including **Dorgan v. Loukas**, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) and **Doe v. Nixon**, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 468 (2012).
**Dorgan v. Loukas**, 19 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns landlord liability for failure to act upon notice of unsafe or intrusive conditions in common areas. Dorgan v. Loukas deals with habitability defects within the tenants’ apartment (a defective furnace causing soot, failure to maintain the apartment, and related c. 93A and quiet enjoyment violations), not with unsafe or intrusive conditions in common areas or common-area notice issues. Thus, while it supports landlord liability for failure to maintain habitable premises, it does not support the more specific common‑areas proposition stated.
**Dorgan v. Loukas**, 19 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The defendants were seriously at fault in failing to bring the plaintiffs’ apartment into habitable condition and to keep it so. Most grievous among the defects was the lamentable condition of the oil fired furnace and connected heating apparatus, which was supposed to deliver clean heat to the apartment, but in fact corrupted it and all within it with clinging soot. Responsibility in the matter, fastened on the landlord by the State Sanitary Code… The defendants were also found, with respect to the condition of the apartment, to have violated the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment…”

**Doe v. Nixon**, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 468.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly found liability for failure to act upon notice of unsafe or intrusive conditions in common areas, including **Dorgan v. Loukas**, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) and **Doe v. Nixon**, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 468 (2012).
**Doe v. Nixon**, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 468.case_name: Audubon Hill South Condominium Ass'n v. Community Ass'n Underwriters of America, Inc.
**Doe v. Nixon**, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 468.support_reasoning: This opinion is an insurance coverage dispute about whether damage from slab subsidence is covered under a condominium policy. It does not address landlord or condominium association liability for failure to act upon notice of unsafe or intrusive conditions in common areas, nor does it discuss Dorgan v. Loukas or any duty to remedy dangerous conditions. Therefore, it does not support the proposition cited.
**Doe v. Nixon**, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 468.relevant_excerpt: These cross appeals present a dispute over insurance coverage. Audubon Hill South Condominium Association (Audubon or association) sued its insurer, Community Association Underwriters of America, Inc. (CAU), to establish coverage of damage to one of its units from the subsidence or tilt of a foundational slab... On appeal we consider the proper scope of the reference or referee process mandated by G. L. c. 175, § 99; the coverage terms of the policy; the proper use of a motion for reconsideration... and the propriety of the denial of CAU’s motion to amend its answer to assert counterclaims.

**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: See also **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (recognizing emotional distress and inconvenience as compensable under §14); **Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989) (landlord liable for failure to address safety issues in common space); **Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 437 Mass. 708 (2002) (quiet enjoyment covenant breached when landlord’s neglect exposes tenant to unreasonable risk); **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (failure to maintain security measures interfered with quiet enjoyment).
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Al‑Ziab recognizes emotional distress and inconvenience as compensable under § 14. This opinion does not discuss the types of damages available under § 14, nor does it mention emotional distress or inconvenience as categories of compensable harm. Instead, it addresses the liability standard under § 14 (requiring at least negligence and notice) and holds that a bare violation of the lead paint statute does not automatically constitute a § 14 violation, ultimately vacating the § 14 attorney’s fees award. It therefore does not support the cited proposition.
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

**Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989).proposition: See also **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (recognizing emotional distress and inconvenience as compensable under §14); **Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989) (landlord liable for failure to address safety issues in common space); **Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 437 Mass. 708 (2002) (quiet enjoyment covenant breached when landlord’s neglect exposes tenant to unreasonable risk); **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (failure to maintain security measures interfered with quiet enjoyment).
**Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989).support_reasoning: The proposition attributes to Pine v. Rust a rule about landlord liability for failure to address safety issues in common space and breach of quiet enjoyment. This opinion, however, is a wiretap/privacy case under G.L. c. 272, § 99, concerning an unlawful secret recording of a tenants’ meeting and related damages and survivability; it does not address landlord duties regarding physical safety, common areas, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, citing Pine v. Rust for that landlord-tenant safety proposition is inaccurate.
**Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989).relevant_excerpt: This action arises under the wiretap statute, G. L. c. 272, § 99 (1986 ed.)… Louise Rust carried a small tape recorder concealed in her purse and clandestinely tape recorded parts of the meeting… The Massachusetts statute, on the other hand, grants a civil remedy to any aggrieved person whose communications were intercepted, disclosed, or used, except as authorized by the statute. G. L. c. 272, § 99 Q.

**Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 4.proposition: See also **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (recognizing emotional distress and inconvenience as compensable under §14); **Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989) (landlord liable for failure to address safety issues in common space); **Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 437 Mass. 708 (2002) (quiet enjoyment covenant breached when landlord’s neglect exposes tenant to unreasonable risk); **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (failure to maintain security measures interfered with quiet enjoyment).
**Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 4.support_reasoning: The proposition attributes to Wesson the rule that the quiet enjoyment covenant is breached when the landlord’s neglect exposes the tenant to unreasonable risk. While Wesson ultimately finds no constructive eviction, it expressly holds that the landlord’s failure to maintain the roof—after notice—breached his covenant and deprived the tenant of a substantial benefit significant to the lease’s purpose. That is materially consistent with the idea that such neglect constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment by exposing the tenant’s operations and property to unreasonable risk, even if framed here through the mutually dependent covenants doctrine rather than §14 specifically.
**Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 4.relevant_excerpt: “Here that substantial benefit was a dry space necessary to safely conduct the high technology printing business for which the landlord knew the premises were to be used…. Based on the judge’s findings of fact, all of the requirements of the rule have been met in this case: the landlord breached his covenant to maintain the roof by failing to adequately repair its chronic leaking; the breach directly interfered with the tenant’s business by depriving it of a substantial benefit significant to the purpose of the lease….”

**Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1.proposition: See also **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (recognizing emotional distress and inconvenience as compensable under §14); **Pine v. Rust**, 404 Mass. 411 (1989) (landlord liable for failure to address safety issues in common space); **Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 437 Mass. 708 (2002) (quiet enjoyment covenant breached when landlord’s neglect exposes tenant to unreasonable risk); **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (failure to maintain security measures interfered with quiet enjoyment).
**Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition attributes to Haddad v. Gonzalez a holding that a landlord’s failure to maintain security measures interfered with quiet enjoyment. This opinion does not address building security, criminal activity, or related safety devices; the quiet enjoyment counterclaim is mentioned only briefly, and the court’s substantive analysis focuses instead on habitability, emotional distress, and Chapter 93A damages. Thus, the case does not stand for the specific security-related quiet enjoyment principle cited.
**Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1.relevant_excerpt: “After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action… the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14… After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims… On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries… emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.”

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct further violates **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, which protects tenants from retaliatory or negligent interference, and **G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L**, requiring landlords to maintain buildings in a sanitary, secure, and habitable condition.

**G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7127A\u2013127.proposition: Defendant’s conduct further violates **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, which protects tenants from retaliatory or negligent interference, and **G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L**, requiring landlords to maintain buildings in a sanitary, secure, and habitable condition.

**G.L. c. 143, \u00a73R**.proposition: Defendant’s knowing failure to repair the lock despite repeated notice also constitutes negligence per se under **G.L. c. 143, §3R**, reflecting a disregard of statutory obligations to maintain safe egress and entry facilities.

**Cormi v. Whitehouse**, 43 Mass. App. C.proposition: Plaintiff may also recover reasonable attorney’s fees and costs even though she is self-represented, under equitable principles recognized in **Simon v. Solomon**, supra, and **Cormi v. Whitehouse**, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 175 (1997).
**Cormi v. Whitehouse**, 43 Mass. App. C.case_name: City of Lynn v. Labor Relations Commission
**Cormi v. Whitehouse**, 43 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion in Cormi v. Whitehouse concerns public-sector labor law and the scope of a fire chief’s managerial prerogative to seek a firefighter’s involuntary retirement. It does not address attorneys’ fees, pro se or otherwise, nor equitable fee-shifting principles. Therefore, it cannot support the proposition that a self-represented plaintiff may recover reasonable attorney’s fees and costs under equitable principles.
**Cormi v. Whitehouse**, 43 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion anywhere in the provided text of attorneys’ fees, costs, fee-shifting, or compensation for legal services, whether for represented or self-represented parties. The case focuses exclusively on whether the fire chief’s authority under G. L. c. 32, § 16(1)(a), is subject to mandatory collective bargaining under G. L. c. 150E.
